Ok, please let me know if you are interested in a pull-request for this issue with ElasticSearch and feel free to discuss on the details

GDPR is a thing now and the _right to be forgotten_ requires distributed long transactions across components. At Typeform we have the following use case.

1. A user action triggers the account deletion which generates a message of deletion in the `user service`.
2. This message is being consumed by many other components in the system, all of them doing long expensive operations of deletion. Some of them include database operations that we control (we can run them at once) but some others include async processes in 3rd parties (e.g. intercom, autopilot, segment, etc.) that we are constantly checking the status.

In terms of observing traces there are two options we explored:
- We propagate the `RequestID` from the very first request being made by the user (a.k.a. clicking on the `Delete my account` button) and create different traces linked by a tag `RequestID`. This is weird but works.
- We pile up everything in the same trace ending up in moster long trace which conceptually is weird: later hops are child of the initial http request but there is no sense in relating them as they don't affect the output of the very first operation nor the subsequent ones. They basically have nothing to do with the top parents but they are there just because we need a way to tie them.

The convenience of having linked traces is not only because we can group traces (that we could do with a tag) but also it allows use to have more meaningful traces, grouping all the effects of a single operations when it comes to async removes the focus from the child effects by them self.

So, could we consider this in the roadmap?

Why not support custom builds?
I want to register zipkin to eureka server, and also get configuration from spring config server.

I had resolved it. Just downgrade springboot2.0 to 1.5.x.
To refrence
https://stackoverflow.com/questions/50027127/zipkin-ui-displaying-error-message-error-cannot-load-service-names-no-message
Well, it is great to upgrade faster the version of springboot dependenced by zipkin-server.jar  :) @adriancole

@chuguoren Well. Firstly, There is nothing stopping you from using custom builds. You can still use it at your own risk. For most of the users, the released versions are sufficient enough for running it production. If you're learning/exploring Zipkin, I would recommend using the released version and if you feel any limitations you can request that feature to be included in the core library or explore the option of running a custom build. 
@nolan4954 - FYI - The latest verision of Zipkin 2.8.4 is using Springboot 2.0.1 under the hood.

> Why not support custom builds?

@chuguoren it's possible we can support more features in the prebuilt Zipkin Server, but we need to gauge user interest and adoption/support for each. Supporting any possible custom build requires an unbounded amount of support resources, while we have limited resources (volunteers and paid staff) to help. As @zeagord explained, using a custom build is still an option, as long as you are willing to support yourself in doing so.

> I want to register zipkin to eureka server

see #1870 for the feature request to support service discovery. You can comment there explaining your situation.

> and also get configuration from spring config server.

I don't think we've had a request for this, so you can be the first to make a ticket for it if you're interested in it and want to see if others are as well.

@zeagord 
I tried to upgrade zipkin-server to 2.8.1 , springboot to 2.0.x
But `@EnableZipkinServer ` cannot be imported. 
And there will be 404 error with zipkin ui home page if doesn't use @EnableZipkinServer
So, It's better to use 2.7.1 v and springboot 1.5.x ?

zipkin Use the released jar or docker version is enough for running it production, Don't need downgrade springboot to 1.5.x,  Custom build zipkinserver with spring Boot is unnecessary, Starting from the Edgware release, the Zipkin Stream server is deprecated. In the Finchley release, it got removed.
@EnableZipkinServer and @EnableZipkinStreamServer is deprecated,
Web
java -jar zipkin-server-2.8.3-exec.jar
Rabbitmq
java -jar zipkin-server-2.8.3-exec.jar --RABBIT_ADDRESSES=localhost:5672 --RABBIT_USER=user --RABBIT_PASSWORD=password --RABBIT_VIRTUAL_HOST=host
kafak
java -jar zipkin-server-2.8.3-exec.jar --KAFKA_ZOOKEEPER=localhost:2181

I register zipkin server to spring cloud eureka server, for other services to discover, and also get configuation from spring cloud config server. We use it by custom maven build, the spring boot version is 1.5.X. When I use spring boot 2.0 build, the UI displays error: "Cannot load service names: No message available"
I have posted a possible solution here: https://github.com/travis-ci/travis-ci/issues/7254#issuecomment-387689631. copying here as this issue is the first in google search

You are the only one to report this eclipse problem, even if we did change something, we'd need verification as I'm very surprised eclipse doesn't work. We have core committers who use eclipse.

WRT workspace, we will continue to have both versions released until such time as we don't require both. Our collector code currently requires both libraries for interop. When I get back from holiday (21 May), I will start working on removing the last dependencies on v1.

I'll mention point-by-point why there will be no action apart from removing the v1 code as soon as we can (which is at any rate a goal).

okhttp is an example of another library which only differs on group ID and package name. It is one of the most popular libraries out there. From a packaging POV we are no different (ex okhttp.jar is for all versions). What's different between us and them is that we still release 2 packages (because we must! not because we are intentionally being annoying)

Most users never have to import our source in the first place. Often times people are importing code, trying to make custom servers (which is unsupported). The larger audience of Zipkin are not affected by this in any way, as there is no such practice in wider repositories such as brave or zipkin-reporter.

TL;DR: I'm closing this out as it will be addressed by removing the v1 library... to conserve hands for larger benefit and cause least disruption while accomplishing the same goal.

Meanwhile, I'd recommend joining gitter to chat with folks about whatever you are importing the code. You might not even need to be doing this.. Not checking out this repo is another way to not be annoyed by it! :D
https://gitter.im/openzipkin/zipkin

Finally, I understand your frustration and appreciate your telling us about it. Closing this issue doesn't mean we won't address the concern. It is just that we won't do it by reorganizing our group IDs etc. It will be by removing the codebase in question as soon as we can. Ideally, but no promises.. in june.

As mentioned on #2046, the only reason you are experiencing a glitch is likely eclipse doesn't know what to name this on override. For example, Intellij names it "zipkin (2)" or something. There's likely a way to do this neater in eclipse, but also mentioned in that issue that this concern will go away when the old library (io.zipkin.java) is removed.

In the future, I wouldn't recommend us dual-publishing libraries for more than a release cycle. Rather, we'd keep a long running `io.zipkin.zipkin3` branch until there is no dependencies on `io.zipkin.zipkin2`. However, we are were we are: there's work to do namely around the collector, UI and also mysql which implies we have at least a person-month of effort to get rid of dependencies on the v1 code.. maybe more than that.

Personally, I will be working on this effort when I return.
why are you importing both artifacts?

see also #2045 #2046 as there are elaborate explanations. (interesting pile-on of issues in such a short time!)

While understood, we won't be changing the group of a deprecated artifact. Rather, we will make it unnecessary. It  already is unnecessary for current versions of Brave, for example.

Feel free to comment here why you are importing both, or let us know on https://gitter.im/openzipkin/zipkin Perhaps there's a way to make this issue unnecessary for you.

@ronperei the recommended and supported way of using the Zipkin Server is running the pre-built Zipkin Server as described in the [quick start instructions](https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin#quick-start). Most users should not need to build anything themselves to run the Zipkin Server. If you have more questions, please feel free to join us on [Gitter](https://gitter.im/openzipkin/zipkin).

PS thought while away:

io.zipkin.zipkin2:zipkin-collector could be a new java 8+ only jar. The only consumer of this code is the server, which is java 8 anyway. This will make things easier as formerly there was tension about the codebase which is only used by the server/collector.

Note: A future version of this collector could do reactive streams (1.0 or via java 9) or other fanciness, but I don't think we should do that now. There is so much work just to migrate off the v1 code we should make sure this completes before working on candy.

Thanks for the notes, Andrey. One little thing is that we don't have
bundling at the storage side at the moment... what this means is the other
side would make a new storage request for each span. Maybe in some
environments that's ok, notably cassandra would be OK. However, bundling
could help those who can take advantage of batching commands.. What are you
using for ultimate storage?

Ahh, I didn't think about what happens on the other end. Do you want me to do the bundling work as part of this PR or a followup PR?

We are running ES right now, but it is on my todo list to research whether ES or Cassandra scales better. Has anyone in the community done an evaluation between the two already?

It is probably better to have a bundling option, and I do wonder if we
shouldn't revisit this as a sender or at least a message queue based
sender, so that we don't end up with a complete copy/paste just for
rabbitMQ instead. cc @shakuzen
:) ... Thanks man

Thinking about it more, bundling seems be to be better done on the storage layer-side; e.g. why should the sender know the optimal bundle size for a storage backend they might not even know about. 

Building off your idea for an MQ based sender; what if Zipkin were to be made to run storage-less and instead an admin could configure MQ ingest instead? The current kafka code probably wouldn't change too much; but get shifted around to be behind a more suitable MQ interface. Batching config could be added later, so there is a batch for MQ, then a separate batch for storage.  

Once I submit the filter interface PR w/ quota filters; putting that stuff in the senders will be dangerous because there is no guarantee that service owners will depend on the correct sender lib and configure it correctly.
Hello, if I don't run zipkin-dependency.jar, can I use POM dependency to start zipkin-server only to achieve the same result?

no.. currently there's no way to do this. the dependency job is offline. We
can consider changing this as so many people ask (to an approach like mysql
which does on-demand if the dependencies job never ran)
yes. After all, there is a dependency button on UI, but it can not display data. It will make some people feel very strange. Thank you for your answer.

>
> Thinking about it more, bundling seems be to be better done on the storage
> layer-side; e.g. why should the sender know the optimal bundle size for a
> storage backend they might not even know about.
>
this is more a point of sending 1 span at a time which is known to not be
efficient, vs believing we know the best bunding size. For example, the
storage layer can rebundle smaller, but only if the input was bundled in
the first place. We don't want to introduce state between different
collector messages (Which is how we'd do bundling in the case where people
only send 1 span)..

> Building off your idea for an MQ based sender; what if Zipkin were to be
> made to run storage-less and instead an admin could configure MQ ingest
> instead? The current kafka code probably wouldn't change too much; but get
> shifted around to be behind a more suitable MQ interface. Batching config
> could be added later, so there is a batch for MQ, then a separate batch for
> storage.
>
I think this is more the proxy use case in general. For example, we've long
had requests for http proxying (which isn't quite as safe as MQ based as
there's no buffer), but could help simplify a backend as that backend only
needs to talk zipkin2. The key here though is to not eliminate batching
which is very much a norm in MQ, without forcing a change to other code
which doesn't have batching by default. The reporter's async reporter does
have working bundling and it is all about the transport, less about
storage. Using that, or an approach derived from that has the least risk.


> Once I submit the filter interface PR w/ quota filters; putting that stuff
> in the senders will be dangerous because there is no guarantee that service
> owners will depend on the correct sender lib and configure it correctly.
>
I'm not sure about the danger part, because we often limit things here
anyway. For example, I don't expect us to make a configuration that is
completely arbitrary. For example, I meant literally rabbit as that's the
other supported MQ. Basically consider how this impacts design. If someone
does something custom using the same code, and misconfigures it.. it is on
them. We are rather strict with what's supported and not, so yeah I would
defer this part (the policy from the mechanism)

On the quota filters and this change in general, I'd caution that depending
on how many features and how the code looks in general it might not be
merged as is. So please do proceed, but keep in mind it might be moved
around, possibly to another repo like we do with zipkin-gcp depending on
how things go. It is really important to know the general features that
will be used in filtering to see the least code needed to accomplish it,
and for example, some of it might move to collector v2.

In other words, please do put in code that does "exactly" what you need as
well, including filtering examples, so that when we think together about
how to enable this, we don't break it in the process.

Cheers and thanks tons!

> Will be nice to see the storage impact before and after, and some throughput difference.

Here you go @adriancole 
These are the numbers for three separate benchmarks, each running for an hour with, as much throughput as possible,
- Cassandra-3.11.2 without the annotations index
- Cassandra-3.11.3 with the new delimiter SASI annotations index
- Cassandra-3.11.2 with the previous CONTAINS SASI annotations index

It's visible from these that the new delimiter SASI annotations index is almost as fast as with no annotations index, both of which are ~20x as fast as the previous CONTAINS SASI annotations index.
Both Cassandra and the stress client ran on the same Lenovo X1 Carbon gen5 (Intel Core i7-5600U Processor, 8Gb RAM) with Ubuntu 17.10.

PS: while zipkin server start, it will create a queue uses it's defaut args. so, conform the target queue is not exists (if exists delete it) ! and DO NOT start zipkin server. we create the queue use different args manually.

arg "x-message-ttl": 36000000

arg "x-max-length-bytes": 300485760

java -jar zipkin-server-2.8.4-exec.jar -server -Xmx128m -Xms128m --management.endpoints.enabled-by-default=true --zipkin.collector.rabbitmq.uri=amqp://user_name:password@hostname:port/vhost --zipkin.collector.rabbitmq.queue=queue.monitor.zipkin --zipkin.collector.rabbitmq.connection-timeout=15000 --zipkin.collector.rabbitmq.concurrency=1

often when you have one trace with a lot of repeated sometimes unrelated
spans in it, it is the result of a "context leak" In java, this could be
caused by inheritable thread local when thread pools that can grow are in
use in your application.  could this be the case?

On Sat, 2 Jun 2018, 03:27 Ryan Michela, <notifications@github.com> wrote:

> *@rmichela* commented on this pull request.

>
> In
> zipkin-server/src/main/java/zipkin/server/internal/ZipkinHttpCollector.java
> <https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin/pull/2072#discussion_r192493494>:
>
> > @@ -56,10 +61,10 @@
>    private HttpHandler next;
>
>    @Autowired ZipkinHttpCollector(StorageComponent storage, CollectorSampler sampler,
> -    CollectorMetrics metrics) {
> +    CollectorMetrics metrics, Optional<List<SpanFilter>> filters) {
>
> The Optional<T> is required so Spring knows the constructor injected
> filters parameter is not required. Without it, the bean graph will fail
> to load at startup when no SpanFilter plugin implementations are
> registered with Spring.
>
> https://stackoverflow.com/a/42135423
>
> 
> You are receiving this because you commented.
> Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub

personally I like the idea of the filters being pure functions so that we
don't have to setup a separate sort of mechanism for exceptions there. if
there are "on error resume next" type concerns, a decorating filter might
be able to silence those things. test cases for what we are expecting here
can help drive design.

this made me also think that this should probably accept collector metrics
so that it can increase dropped spans if it drops some.

Quick answer is that if a collector being down causes a failure in a application request, that implies a bug in the tracer or the tracer design.

That said, this question is open-ended so better asked on gitter. Please chat for more info if this didn't answer. We use issues for changes to the codebase https://gitter.im/openzipkin/zipkin

Sure, just wanted to clarify my question again in case we are not in the same page. 
Collector getting down does not necessary mean bug in tracer. We deployed collector as a separate remote service, it can be down on its own, and I'm just wondering how instrumented service would handle the connection error.

no I mean that if the tracer stops working because of a temporary
interruption in the collector, it would be a bug. If the tracer causes
memory problems due to long term outage, also a bug. I agree that
collectors can go down. Also, though keep in mind that connections like
this are more brittle when using http transport. Kafka decouples collectors
for example.

Anyway feel free to chat with us if you like more info!
